questions.text: Which segment of the facial nerve is most likely to be affected by ischemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Labyrinthine segment:

  • Narrowest and shortest segment.
  • The only segment of the facial nerve that lacks anastomosing arterial cascades and so is vulnerable to embolic phenomena, low-flow states and vascular compression.
  • It is most likely to be affected by ischaemia in the event of oedema following trauma or inflammation.
  • Also known as the physiological Bottleneck part of the facial nerve.

questions.text:
Facial nerve testing can be clinically done in suspected acute facial nerve palsy by all except?
A. Orbicularis oculi closure
B. Buccinator action
C. Chewing
D. Elevation of eyebrows
E. Checking for angle of the mouth
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chewing is performed by the muscles of mastication(Masseter, Temporalis, Pterygoids). These are supplied by the trigeminal nerve.
  • So, Facial nerve testing can't be done by the chewing action.
  • Muscles of facial expression, such as orbicularis oculi, buccinator, are supplied by the facial nerve.

questions.text: A patient of head injury has bluish discolouration over the mastoid area, bleeding from EAC and complains of hearing loss with normal facial nerve function. After three days, the patient starts having facial weakness. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Delayed facial nerve injury is due to the longitudinal fracture of the temporal bone.

Features of Longitudinal fracture:

  • This is due to falling on the side.
  • 80% of total fractures.
  • Less dangerous.
  • Caused by Ossicular dislocation.
  • Cause CHL
  • Vertigo is uncommon.
  • EAC bleedingand CSF otorrhoea are more Common
  • Facial palsy is less common and delayed, and it is due to edema of the nerve. So, treatment is oral steroids for three weeks.

choices.text: Collection of fluid in the middle ear

questions.text: A patient with a head injury presents with unilateral conductive hearing loss and bleeding in the ear. The tympanic membrane is intact on examination. The battle sign is positive in the patient. The most probable cause for deafness could be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a case of longitudinal fracture of the temporal bone. The ear bleeding is a feature of a longitudinal fracture. This fracture is due to a parietal blow.
  • Battle sign is ecchymosis around the mastoid tip area, which is seen in temporal bone fractures. This fracture causes ossicular dislocation and, hence, conductive hearing loss.

Features of longitudinal and transverse temporal bone fractures:

  • Longitudinal fracture:
    • This is due to falling on the side.
    • 80% of total fractures.
    • Less dangerous.
    • Causes: Ossicular dislocation, most commonly the incudostapedial joint(Option C ruled out).
    • Cause CHL
    • Vertigo is uncommon.
    • EAC bleeding and CSF otorrhoea are more Common
    • Facial palsy is less common and delayed, and it is due to edema of the nerve. So, treatment is oral steroids.
  • Transverse fracture:
    • Due to a Fall on the front or the back.
    • 20% of total fractures.
    • More dangerous.
    • Damage the cochlea. (Option B ruled out).
    • Cause SNHL
    • Vertigo is common.
    • EAC bleeding and CSF otorrhoea are less common
    • Facial palsy is more common and immediate it is due to direct injury to the nerve by the fracture line.
    • So, treatment is immediate Surgery.

questions.text: A patient with Bell's palsy shows no improvement after 3 weeks of steroid therapy. His electroneuronography reveals no significant facial nerve degeneration. What should be the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Treatment of Bell's palsy:

  • Oral steroids for 3 weeks.
  • If no improvement, Electroneuronography is done.
    • If electroneuronography shows no significant facial nerve degeneration, steroid therapy is continued with repeat assessment.
    • Facial nerve decompression would have been done if electroneuronography showed significant facial nerve degeneration(Option C ruled out)
  • A patient who reports within the first three days should be given acyclovir as well, and it is not added after the steroid therapy. (Option A ruled out).
  • Transtympanic dexamethasone is not a usual option and is preserved only for refractory cases. (Option D ruled out)
  • Care of the eye is a very important part of management to prevent exposure keratitis. The chances of recovery in Bell's palsy are 85% or above.

choices.text: A sequel of facial nerve injury
Aberrant regeneration of secretomotor fibres to lacrimal glands
Due to auriculotemporal nerve injury during parotid surgery

questions.text: Which is not true about crocodile tears?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Crocodile tears(gustatory lacrimation): This is due to faulty regeneration of parasympathetic fibres, which now supply the lacrimal gland instead of the salivary glands. (Option B and C ruled out).
  • It is a sequence of the facial nerve injury. (Option A ruled out)
  • Frey's syndrome(gustatory sweating) is a rare neurological disorder resulting from damage to the auriculotemporal nerve during parotid surgery.
  • Hence, Option D is related to Frey's syndrome and not to Crocodile tears.

questions.text: What is the intervention for facial nerve injury immediately following head trauma and fracture of the temporal bone?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Treatment of facial nerve injury following Temporal bone fracture:

  • Immediate onset of facial paralysis following temporal bone fracture - Surgery in the form of nerve decompression, re-anastomosis of cut ends or cable nerve graft.
  • Delayed onset facial paralysis following temporal bone fracture is treated conservatively like Bell's palsy.

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding Bell's palsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Facial paralysis along with vesicular rash in the external auditory canal and pinna is seen in Ramsay Hunt Syndrome(Herpes Zoster Oticus).

Bell’s Palsy:

  • Sixty to seventy-five per cent of lower motor neuron facial paralysis is due to Bell’s palsy. It is defined as idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset. (Option C ruled out).
  • Both sexes are affected frequently. Any age group may be affected, though incidence rises with increasing age.
  • A positive family history is present in 6–8% of patients. The risk of Bell's palsy is higher in diabetics (angiopathy)(Option D ruled out)and pregnant women (retention of fluid).

Clinical features:

  • Onset is sudden. The patient is unable to close his eye. On attempting to close the eye, the eyeball turns up and out (Bell phenomenon).
  • Saliva dribbles from the angle of the mouth. The face becomes asymmetrical. Tears flow down from the eye (epiphora). Pain in the ear may precede or accompany the nerve paralysis.
  • Some complain of noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis)(Option B ruled out)or loss of taste (involvement of the chorda tympani). Paralysis may be complete or incomplete. Bell's palsy is recurrent in 3–10% of patients.

Diagnosis:

  • Diagnosis is always by exclusion. All other known causes of peripheral facial paralysis should be excluded.
  • This requires careful history, complete otological and head and neck examination, X-ray studies, blood tests such as total count, peripheral smear, sedimentation rate, blood sugar and serology.
  • Nerve excitability tests are done daily or on alternate days and compared with the normal side to monitor nerve degeneration.
  • Localising the site of the lesion (topodiagnosis) helps in establishing the aetiology and also the site of surgical decompression of the nerve, if that becomes necessary.

Treatment:

  • Oral steroids for 3 weeks.
  • If no improvement ->Electroneuronography is done
    • If electroneuronography shows no significant facial nerve degeneration, steroid therapy is continued with repeat assessment.
    • Facial nerve decompression would have been done if electroneuronography showed significant facial nerve degeneration.
  • A patient who reports within the first three days should be given acyclovir as well.
  • Care of the eye is a very important part of management to prevent exposure keratitis.

Prognosis:

  • Eighty-five to ninety per cent of the patients recover fully. Ten to fifteen per cent recover incompletely and may be left with some stigmata of degeneration.
  • Recurrent facial palsy may not recover fully. Prognosis is good in incomplete Bell palsy (95% complete recovery) and in those where clinical recovery starts within 3 weeks of onset (75% complete recovery).

questions.text: In a patient with facial nerve injury, Schirmer's test shows normal lacrimation, stapedial reflex is present, and taste sensation is impaired. Where is the level of injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Taste sensation is through the Chorda Tympani, and it is the branch of the vertical segment. Hence, the level of injury is at the vertical segment.

Facial nerve:

  • It enters the temporal bone via the internal auditory canal (internal auditory meatus), and it comes out through the stylomastoid foramen.

Intratemporal part of the facial nerve:

  • In the ear, it travels through a bony canal called the Fallopian canal.
  • It has four segments.
  • Meatal segment-It is within the internal auditory canal (IAC).
  • Labyrinthine segment-It is the narrowest segment; therefore, it is also called the Battle neck of the facial nerve.
  • Horizontal or tympanic segment-It lies on the medial wall of the middle ear. It is from 1st Genu to 2nd Genu. This segment has the highest incidence of Natural dehiscence of the bony facial nerve canal. 1st genu contains a ganglion called the Geniculate ganglion.
  • Mastoid segment.

Surgical landmark:

  • 1st Genu-Processus cochleaformis
  • 2nd Genu-lateral SCC

Branches of the facial nerve within the ear:

  1. Greater superficial Petrosal nerve (Tear)
    • It arises from the 1st genu.
    • It gives the secretomotor supply to the lacrimal glands.
    • A test of this nerve is the Schirmer's test.
  2. Nerve to Stapedius-
    • It arises from the 2nd genu.
    • The test for this nerve is the Stapedial reflex (Protects the inner ear from Loud sounds)
  3. Chorda tympani Nerve- (TASTE)
    • It arises from the vertical segment or mastoid segment of the facial nerve.
    • It passes between the malleus and the incus in the middle ear cavity and exits through the Canal of Huguier(it lies in the petrotympanic fissure). It supplies Taste sensation to the anterior 3rd of the tongue.
    • The test for this nerve is the taste sensation.

questions.text: In a patient of facial nerve injury, Schirmer's test shows decreased lacrimation, taste sensation is impaired and stapedial reflex is absent. Where is the level of injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Topodiagnostic Tests:

  • Schirmer's Test - Reduced lacrimation - lesion proximal to geniculate ganglion(first genu)
  • Stapedial Reflex - Lost in lesions above the Nerve to the stapedius (second genu)
  • Taste test - Impairment of taste means a lesion above the chorda tympani origin.

In the above scenario:

  • Lacrimation - absent
  • Stapedial reflex - Absent
  • Taste sensation - Impaired

So the level of lesion is above the first genu, in the labyrinthine segment.

questions.text:
A patient with recurrent episodes of facial paralysis has the following findings on examination of the oral cavity


What is the name of this entity?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Melkersson-Rosenthal Syndrome Consists of a Triad of:

  • Recurrent facial paralysis
  • Swelling of the lips
  • Fissured tongue

Explanation of other options:

Van Der Hoeve Syndrome(Option A):

  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta
  • Blue Sclera
  • Otosclerosis

Moebius Syndrome(Option C):

  • Congenital facial paralysis (bilateral or unilateral)
  • Inability to move eyes laterally (due to VI nerve palsy)

Gradenigo syndrome(Option D):

  • Otitis media
  • Pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (CN V)
  • Abducens nerve palsy (CN VI)

questions.text: A patient presents with right-sided Bell's palsy and facial asymmetry. Which of the following statements best describes the typical facial deviation observed in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In Bell's palsy of the right side right complete half of the paralysed, with the angle of the mouth deviated to the contralateral side.
  • It affects both upper and lower parts of the face on the same (ipsilateral) side.
  • The forehead (upper face) is involved because LMN lesions paralyse the entire facial musculature on one side.
  • The angle of the mouth is pulled to the opposite (contralateral) side due to the unopposed action of muscles on the normal side.

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Recovery is seen in 50% patients only. So the Option B in the above question is not true about Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome:

  • Also known as Herpes zoster oticus.
  • It is due to the reactivation of Varicella zoster virus in the Geniculate ganglion of the facial Nerve(Option C ruled out).
  • It is a lower motor neuron facial palsy (Option A ruled out).

Clinical features:

  • Painful vesicle in the external ear(Option D ruled out).
  • 7th nerve- Lower motor neuron facial palsy (ipsilateral)

Treatment:

  • Acyclovir and steroid therapy.
